Convention of the Civil St rvice Reform
League Brings Prominent Figures to McCoy Hall.

Homewood Fund Still Growing—Undergraduates Help Two Million Mark
the Aim of Committee.

The thirtieth annual convention
of the National Civil . Service Reform. League.. opened in the Donovan Room, at -eleven o'clock, last
Thursday morning, with Dr. Chas.
W. Eliot _ president emeritus of
Harvard University, in the chair.
At the Thursday morning session, Richard Henry Dana, of New
York, presented the report of the
National Council of the League.
Herbert E. Fleming, secretary of
the Illinois and Chicago
, Civil Service Reform Association, delivered
an address on the connection between civil service reform and the
good government movement in his
own State. In the afternoon, Dr.
Eliot presented the report of the
Committee on l'romotions. At
eight o'clock in the evening, a public meeting was held in McCoy
Hall, with Hon. Charles J. Bonaparte, president of the Maryland
branch of the League, presiding.
The delegates •numbered about
two hundred. Among them were
included sonic of the most distinguished reformers in the country.
Besides Dr. Eliot, Mr. Dana, and
Mr. Fleming, such men were present ;As Commissioner of Indian
Affairs Valentine, Mr. Dudley
Foulke, civil service commissioner,
under the Roosevelt administration,
John T. Doyle; chairman of the
Federal -Civil. Service Commission,
and Hon. Charles J. Bonaparte,
former attorney general of the
United States.
The convention was marked by
several social entertainments. Wednesday evening Mr. and Mrs. Bonaparte entertained at their home on
Park avenue, Mr. Dana, Mr. Valentine, and a few other delegates.
The whole body of delegates were
given a luncheon Thursday afternoon in McCoy Hall by the Women's Auxiliary to the Maryland
Civil Service Reform Association.
Thursday evening, Mr. 'and Mrs.
Bonaparte gave a dinner, at which
Dr. Eliot was the guest of honor.
Dr. Eliot was entertained by the
Harvard Club, Friday afternoon,
at the Baltimore Cluli At the same
time the rest of the delegates were
entertained by Mrs. George H.
Williams at her home on Cathedral
street. The convention was brought
to a close with a banquet at the
Belvedere, Friday night.
Ice hockey is the great winter
sport at Carnegie Tech. With
timore's present weather we might
even have a hockey team ourselves.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 19, 1910.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure
in printing in this issue an authoritative statement from the special
committee appointed by the Athletic Board to consider the financial
situation, which shows that conditions are much more satisfactory
than the figures first obtained seemed to indicate. The problem of securing an accurate analysis of the
figures is fairly complex, and
is to be regretted that through certain misunderstandings, fears that
now appear groundless, regarding
the prospects for lacrosse and baseball, should have been raised.
In this connection, it should not
he forgotten that the trustees are
deserving of the gratitude of the
Athletic Association for generously
absolving the Board from. all obligations for payment on the new
stand this year. With the increased
prestige of the football team and
the growing public interest in Hopkins sports, the Association will
dorbtless be able to make ample
returns to the trustees in the future.
It is rumored that Mr. John M.
Holmes, who has been president of
the Athletic Association for some
six years, intends to hand in his
resignation at the next meeting of
the Board. THE NEWS-LETTER
joins the student body in an appeal
to the Board to refuse to accept
the resignation, and to Mr. Holmes
to reconsider his decision. That
the position is a thankless one, and
that it involves not only work and
worry, but tlso lays its occupant
open to undeserved criticism from
unthinking people, we fully realize.
But we are convinced that Mr.
Holmes is the logical man for the
place, both because of his experience and ability and because of
the uniform tactfulness with which

How can the undergraduates
help in the present campaign? It
would be a great assistance to the
General Campaign Committee if
the undergraduates would make up
a sum to be contributted to the
Endowment and Extension Fund.
This idea, which was briefly set
forth in last week's NEWS-LETTER,
is an admirable one. There are
over one hundred and seventy-five
students at the University, and if
every one were to sign a pledge
for $6, payable in three instalments,
one 1911, 1912, and 1913, it would
mean practically a contribution of
a thousand dollars from the University. To show how low an average this is, the General Committee has already received seven
pledges from students at the University totalling in all $270. The
chief point, however, is that everybody should give something. If
you don't think you can afford to
pay $6 in three years, make it half
that sum, but be sure to contribute
something. Do not hesitate a moment because the sum you can
pledge seems so small in a large
campaign. Everything helps. We
have had numerous contributions
from alumni of $5, and some as
low as $2. If everyone at the University could see the splendid work
which is being done by the Citizens'
Committee, a committee composed
of men not connected with the
University in any way, and many
not connected with any university,
it would not but prove a deep inspiration. When prominent men of
this type give up several hours of
each already overcrowded day to
help the University to Homewood,
certainly the undergraduates should
show their appreciation by swelling the campaign fund at least
$1,000. Alake it a lump sum
either from the classes or from the
undergraduates as a whole. Examination time is always a busy
one, but the Citizens' Committee
and every other committee is equally busy. The only way to decide
a matter of this kind is to do it.
H. FINDLAY FRENCH.

PORT ANTONIO TO KINGSTON
Travels of Biologists on the Island of
Jamaica and eaaly experiences.
1. R. MIDDLETON AND H. H. YORK
(Continued from No. 7)

'We left the reader at the close
of the last article at the wharf of
the United Fruit Company, at Port
Antonio at about seven o'clock.
I hanks to the correspondence that
had previously been held between
the University and the customs
officials at Port Antonio, we had
no trouble whatever with the Customs inspectors (none of us was
required to open his private luggage); and so we soon found ourselves in vehicles that the Jamaicans
call "buggies," which were twoseated affairs, each one capable of
holding four persons. We were
driven to the Titchfield Cottages,
where we left our suitcases and
then drove out to Blue Hole.
A greater part of the distance to
Blue Hole the road was lined on
either side by hedges of a plant
Which was loaded with large
flowers, some white, some red,
some purple, much the form of
very large morning glories, except
that the pistils and stameRs were
qtilte large and conspicuous. These
flowers are called by the natives,
"boot-black" flowers, from the fact
that when they are crushed by rubbing them against one's shoe, they
produce a very nice blacking. It
Is the Hibiscus plant. In places our
road led along the seashore, and
coral reefs were quite conspicuous,
from the red algae growing so plentifully on them. Along this road, too,
We made our first acquaintance with
the chocolate tree, the alspice, and
calabash tree, with its large gourdlike fruits which grow on the trunk
and branches, and whose rind is
sometimes used for cooking utensils
by the natives. It will be remembered that we stated in the first
installment of this article that the
mountains are quite close to the
seashore; along this road we saw
Places where the edges of the foothills had been graded away to make
room for it. We stopped our teams
several *times to get out and to make
a closer inspection of these, and on
the rocks, in damp places, we found
liverworts and mosses.
At one place the road to Blue
Hole crosses a stream of considerable size and here we saw native
Women washing clothes. The natives all go barefooted, and these

If the football team loses money,
CUSS the Athletic Board.
If the football team makes eleven
barrels of gold dollars, cuss the
Athletic Board for not making
them turn over twelve barrels.
If you don't deserve an "H' and
don't get one, • cuss the Athletic
Board fdr not having the rules
changed so as to give you one.
If a track man stumps his toe
and finishes second, cuss the Athletic Board for not providing better
shoes.
If the football team has a training table, cuss the Athletic Board
for allowing the expense..
If the football team does not have
a training table,. cuss the Athletic
Board for being stingy and overcautious with the. funds.
If a lacrosse man breaks his stick
just as he is about to shoot the
winning goal, cuss the Athletic
Board for their lack of foresight
in . not having • the stick wrapped
with tar. tape.
If our team faces the wind in a
punting duel, cuss. the Athletic
Board for allowing such a wind
on a football day.
If our team has the wind At. its
back, thank the weather man and
cuss the Athletic Board for not
ordering more wind.
It does not make any difference
what goes wrong or right in jathletics, nor does it make any difference whose fault it is, cuss, cuss,
cuss the Athletic Board.
For the largest noise, look for
the smallest freshman.
If you don't like the way things
are run around here, tell President
Remsen. Ile will have it changed
for you.
After complaining about the lack
of spirit among the students, try
to show some yourself, as your
very complaint shows that you
haven't very much.

\Vilmer Ray was unanimously.
re-elected captain of the sophomore
track and field team at a meeting
held -last Monday afternoon. The
SDphornores have already begun
training for the dual Meet with
the freshmen, which will take place
sometime next month. Among the
sophomores who will probably
compete are Captain- Ray, E. J.
Pieper, Edward Novak, 0. M. Gillet, A. E. Sattler, Bosley Siegmund,
C. I,. Getz, 0. K. Schmied, 14. L.
Jacobs, Leo Brady,Lewis T. Breuninger, Hans 1\1 elamet and G. E. W.
Hardy.
The sophomores also, decided to
organize a class basketball team,
but postponed the election of captain to the next class meeting.
Class numerals were unanimously
awarded to President Ray, Getz,
Novak and Jacobs for getting hands
on the cane in the cane-rush.
The class decided to send Edmond S. Donoho, who is at present
confined to his bed at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, as a result of an
injury in the inter-class football
game, a handsome Hopkins pillow.
Gillet, Sattler and Getz, were appointe(l as a committee to carry out
this plan.

Ross Miles Diggs, Prominent Young Attorney, Succumbs to I yphoid
Fever.

Ross M des Diggs, '02, died on
December 5, at the St. Joseph's
Hospital, Baltimore, after a twoweeks' illness, with typhoid fever,
at the age of twenty-nine years.
Mr. Diggs was a prominent young
attorney of this city, and treasurer
of the Baltimore Bar Association.
Besides this, he was a member.of
the Maryland State Library Commission, secretary of the Society
of the War of 1812, vice-president
of the Baltimore Council National
Union, a member of the St. Andrew's Society, and director and
counsel .of the Female House of
Refuge. Mr. Diggs was also interested in charitable organizations
and was prominently identified
with settlement work in this city.
Mr. Diggs graduated from Hopkins with an A. 11., in 1902. He
then took up the study of law at
the University of Maryland, from
which he graduated with honors.
Since his graduation from the law
school, and until his death, he was
a member .of the firm .of Hinkley &
Morris, well known Baltimore attorneys.

Convention of the Civil St rvice Reform
League Brings Prominent Figures to McCoy Hall.

Homewood Fund Still Growing—Undergraduates Help Two Million Mark
the Aim of Committee.

The thirtieth annual convention
of the National Civil . Service Reform. League.. opened in the Donovan Room, at -eleven o'clock, last
Thursday morning, with Dr. Chas.
W. Eliot _ president emeritus of
Harvard University, in the chair.
At the Thursday morning session, Richard Henry Dana, of New
York, presented the report of the
National Council of the League.
Herbert E. Fleming, secretary of
the Illinois and Chicago
, Civil Service Reform Association, delivered
an address on the connection between civil service reform and the
good government movement in his
own State. In the afternoon, Dr.
Eliot presented the report of the
Committee on l'romotions. At
eight o'clock in the evening, a public meeting was held in McCoy
Hall, with Hon. Charles J. Bonaparte, president of the Maryland
branch of the League, presiding.
The delegates •numbered about
two hundred. Among them were
included sonic of the most distinguished reformers in the country.
Besides Dr. Eliot, Mr. Dana, and
Mr. Fleming, such men were present ;As Commissioner of Indian
Affairs Valentine, Mr. Dudley
Foulke, civil service commissioner,
under the Roosevelt administration,
John T. Doyle; chairman of the
Federal -Civil. Service Commission,
and Hon. Charles J. Bonaparte,
former attorney general of the
United States.
The convention was marked by
several social entertainments. Wednesday evening Mr. and Mrs. Bonaparte entertained at their home on
Park avenue, Mr. Dana, Mr. Valentine, and a few other delegates.
The whole body of delegates were
given a luncheon Thursday afternoon in McCoy Hall by the Women's Auxiliary to the Maryland
Civil Service Reform Association.
Thursday evening, Mr. 'and Mrs.
Bonaparte gave a dinner, at which
Dr. Eliot was the guest of honor.
Dr. Eliot was entertained by the
Harvard Club, Friday afternoon,
at the Baltimore Cluli At the same
time the rest of the delegates were
entertained by Mrs. George H.
Williams at her home on Cathedral
street. The convention was brought
to a close with a banquet at the
Belvedere, Friday night.
Ice hockey is the great winter
sport at Carnegie Tech. With
timore's present weather we might
even have a hockey team ourselves.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 19, 1910.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure
in printing in this issue an authoritative statement from the special
committee appointed by the Athletic Board to consider the financial
situation, which shows that conditions are much more satisfactory
than the figures first obtained seemed to indicate. The problem of securing an accurate analysis of the
figures is fairly complex, and
is to be regretted that through certain misunderstandings, fears that
now appear groundless, regarding
the prospects for lacrosse and baseball, should have been raised.
In this connection, it should not
he forgotten that the trustees are
deserving of the gratitude of the
Athletic Association for generously
absolving the Board from. all obligations for payment on the new
stand this year. With the increased
prestige of the football team and
the growing public interest in Hopkins sports, the Association will
dorbtless be able to make ample
returns to the trustees in the future.
It is rumored that Mr. John M.
Holmes, who has been president of
the Athletic Association for some
six years, intends to hand in his
resignation at the next meeting of
the Board. THE NEWS-LETTER
joins the student body in an appeal
to the Board to refuse to accept
the resignation, and to Mr. Holmes
to reconsider his decision. That
the position is a thankless one, and
that it involves not only work and
worry, but tlso lays its occupant
open to undeserved criticism from
unthinking people, we fully realize.
But we are convinced that Mr.
Holmes is the logical man for the
place, both because of his experience and ability and because of
the uniform tactfulness with which

How can the undergraduates
help in the present campaign? It
would be a great assistance to the
General Campaign Committee if
the undergraduates would make up
a sum to be contributted to the
Endowment and Extension Fund.
This idea, which was briefly set
forth in last week's NEWS-LETTER,
is an admirable one. There are
over one hundred and seventy-five
students at the University, and if
every one were to sign a pledge
for $6, payable in three instalments,
one 1911, 1912, and 1913, it would
mean practically a contribution of
a thousand dollars from the University. To show how low an average this is, the General Committee has already received seven
pledges from students at the University totalling in all $270. The
chief point, however, is that everybody should give something. If
you don't think you can afford to
pay $6 in three years, make it half
that sum, but be sure to contribute
something. Do not hesitate a moment because the sum you can
pledge seems so small in a large
campaign. Everything helps. We
have had numerous contributions
from alumni of $5, and some as
low as $2. If everyone at the University could see the splendid work
which is being done by the Citizens'
Committee, a committee composed
of men not connected with the
University in any way, and many
not connected with any university,
it would not but prove a deep inspiration. When prominent men of
this type give up several hours of
each already overcrowded day to
help the University to Homewood,
certainly the undergraduates should
show their appreciation by swelling the campaign fund at least
$1,000. Alake it a lump sum
either from the classes or from the
undergraduates as a whole. Examination time is always a busy
one, but the Citizens' Committee
and every other committee is equally busy. The only way to decide
a matter of this kind is to do it.

'We left the reader at the close
of the last article at the wharf of
the United Fruit Company, at Port
Antonio at about seven o'clock.
I hanks to the correspondence that
had previously been held between
the University and the customs
officials at Port Antonio, we had
no trouble whatever with the Customs inspectors (none of us was
required to open his private luggage); and so we soon found ourselves in vehicles that the Jamaicans
call "buggies," which were twoseated affairs, each one capable of
holding four persons. We were
driven to the Titchfield Cottages,
where we left our suitcases and
then drove out to Blue Hole.
A greater part of the distance to
Blue Hole the road was lined on
either side by hedges of a plant
Which was loaded with large
flowers, some white, some red,
some purple, much the form of
very large morning glories, except
that the pistils and stameRs were
qtilte large and conspicuous. These
flowers are called by the natives,
"boot-black" flowers, from the fact
that when they are crushed by rubbing them against one's shoe, they
produce a very nice blacking. It
Is the Hibiscus plant. In places our
road led along the seashore, and
coral reefs were quite conspicuous,
from the red algae growing so plentifully on them. Along this road, too,
We made our first acquaintance with
the chocolate tree, the alspice, and
calabash tree, with its large gourdlike fruits which grow on the trunk
and branches, and whose rind is
sometimes used for cooking utensils
by the natives. It will be remembered that we stated in the first
installment of this article that the
mountains are quite close to the
seashore; along this road we saw
Places where the edges of the foothills had been graded away to make
room for it. We stopped our teams
several *times to get out and to make
a closer inspection of these, and on
the rocks, in damp places, we found
liverworts and mosses.
At one place the road to Blue
Hole crosses a stream of considerable size and here we saw native

\Vilmer Ray was unanimously.
re-elected captain of the sophomore
track and field team at a meeting
held -last Monday afternoon. The
SDphornores have already begun
training for the dual Meet with
the freshmen, which will take place
sometime next month. Among the
sophomores who will probably
compete are Captain- Ray, E. J.
Pieper, Edward Novak, 0. M. Gillet, A. E. Sattler, Bosley Siegmund,
C. I,. Getz, 0. K. Schmied, 14. L.
Jacobs, Leo Brady,Lewis T. Breuninger, Hans 1\1 elamet and G. E. W.
Hardy.
The sophomores also, decided to
organize a class basketball team,
but postponed the election of captain to the next class meeting.
Class numerals were unanimously
awarded to President Ray, Getz,
Novak and Jacobs for getting hands
on the cane in the cane-rush.
The class decided to send Edmond S. Donoho, who is at present
confined to his bed at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, as a result of an
injury in the inter-class football
game, a handsome Hopkins pillow.
Gillet, Sattler and Getz, were appointe(l as a committee to carry out
this plan.

Ross Miles Diggs, Prominent Young Attorney, Succumbs to I yphoid
Fever.

Ross M des Diggs, '02, died on
December 5, at the St. Joseph's
Hospital, Baltimore, after a twoweeks' illness, with typhoid fever,
at the age of twenty-nine years.
Mr. Diggs was a prominent young
attorney of this city, and treasurer
of the Baltimore Bar Association.
Besides this, he was a member.of
the Maryland State Library Commission, secretary of the Society
of the War of 1812, vice-president
of the Baltimore Council National
Union, a member of the St. Andrew's Society, and director and
counsel .of the Female House of
Refuge. Mr. Diggs was also interested in charitable organizations
and was prominently identified
with settlement work in this city.
Mr. Diggs graduated from Hopkins with an A. 11., in 1902. He
then took up the study of law at
the University of Maryland, from
which he graduated with honors.
Since his graduation from the law
school, and until his death, he was
a member .of the firm .of Hinkley &
Morris, well known Baltimore attorneys.
